Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: My phone buzzed in my apron pocket just as I started counting the cash drawer at the end of my shift. I knew it was Mom—she always texted around this time, wanting to hear about my day and make sure I was okay. We had this unspoken rule: I’d reply quickly, tell her about work, and reassure her that everything was fine. But tonight, the register was off by a few dollars, and my manager hovered nearby, watching me recount every bill and receipt. My hands shook as I tried to focus, but the phone kept vibrating, each buzz a reminder of my promise to Mom. I could almost hear her voice in my head, worried if I didn’t answer soon. I felt torn—if I stopped to text her, I might make another mistake with the money, but if I ignored her, she’d worry all night. The pressure from both sides pressed in on me, and I stood there, caught between being a good daughter and a responsible cashier, not sure which role to answer first.
